page.title: 18THATCHING, HOPTON
page.content: Many roofs in this area are thatched. In Norfolk, reed (rye and wheat can be used) is usually used. Damp straw is gathered together in yealms 18ins. wide and 5ins. deep and laid in a y-shaped yoke (large end forward), then overlapped and pegged down with staple-like hazel spars. Loose straw is raked out. Batterns are fixed across the rafters at intervals of 5, 9 and finally 2ins from the vertical board starting at the bottom. Flat thatching is covered by roofing and the yealms are bent and secured. A pattern can be cut. Lastly the eaves are cut level at the bottom. This is used on roofs pitched at least 50 degrees (so the rain will run off) where rafters overhang the walls. Thatched roofs last about 20 years and are costly to insure as they are high fire risks, but are very attractive.
